title: interface inconsistency with char::is_ascii_... functions

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
There is an interface inconsistency between `char::is_ascii_...` and other `char::is_...` functions. The first all take a reference to a `char`, the latter take a `char`.

This causes point-free style on many `str` functions to be possible with the non-ascii `char::is_...` functions, but not with the `char::is_ascii_...` functions, e.g. see the examples at [`str::split`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.split) for what is possible.

### concrete example
This works:
```rust
let s="a b";
assert_eq!(s.find(char::is_whitespace), Some(1));
```
This does not work:
```rust
let s="a b";
assert_eq!(s.find(char::is_ascii_whitespace), Some(1));
```
The error is:
```text
error[E0631]: type mismatch in function arguments
[...]
expected signature of `fn(char) -> _`
found signature of `for<'r> fn(&'r char) -> _`
note: required because of the requirements on the impl of `std::str::pattern::Pattern<'_>` for
      `for<'r> fn(&'r char) -> bool {std::char::methods::<impl char>::is_ascii_digit}`
```

I think this might be an oversight from porting AsciiExt. I am aware that the API can probably not be changed anymore. But maybe there is another solution?
